bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, October 9, 1900

div1.p: Reed teases Emilie Lawrence Reed and Blossom Reed. He writes that Carroll is on a month's leave. He describes cases of dysentery.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, October 9, 1900
div1.opener:
Tell fat
monkey
to write to
me--
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
Oct. 9th 1900.
My precious wifie;
div1.p:
Well done,
fat oomsey! Here I have
a letter of Oct. 4th received
on yesterday- It makes
me, in reading it, very happy that
my darling wifie is be-
ginning to take interest
in things again & especially
in her bad old Mr Mantee,
I am so glad that you
got your trunk in good
shape, but very sorry
that you didn't see Gen.
Lee- He is so jolly and
pleasant that I know
that you would have
liked him &, also, enjoyed
his conversation- Never
mind, Miss Room-Fixer,
when you come down to
see me, for a little visit of
two weeks before I start
back, you will see him
then & make his acquain-
tance- Isn't it so nice
that dear little Cocoon
has such a nice school
and such a pleasant walk
to it? Bless her darling heart,
she must be a very smart
child & practice her
music faithfully & study
her English History, too.
Do you find your rooms
comfortable & cosy now?
I am sure that you do-
and how does Doogy
& Cricket get along? Are
they as good friends as
ever? The time is passing
here very rapidly- I have
been very busy with
working on our prelim-
inary report, which is of
absorbing interest- What
a mysterious world this
is any how? and what dread-
ful enemies man's oldest
acquaintances are! I'll tell
you all about this when
I get back- Dr Carroll leaves
on the Crook tomorrow, to be
gone 30 days- I found that he
was more homesick than
anything else- I am sorry to
see him go, but as it inter-
rupts the work very much,
but there are some interest-
ing cases of dysentery here
that I can study without
any danger!! Don't worry
about my seeing a few
cases of dysentery, please
sweetheart- What's at the
theatres now days? Did you
and Cocoon go to see the play
after I left? I hope so-
Well, Farmer-lady, I am getting
sleepy and I am going to bed
so good-night, you sweet Joy! Boo! Boo!
Wednesday morning, Octr 10th, Well,
good morning Miss sleepy
farmer - lady! Why don't you
get up & wake that other
fatty up, so that you
can both enjoy the Sun-
rise with old Mr Mantee!
What lazy, lazy people
you are anyway! Here
it is 6.30 o'clock and Mr
Bad man has had his
“galorious” shower - bath
of the purest and most
evenly - temperatured
spring - water in the
world, and is here writing
to Oh! such a sweet lady and
she, by Jingo, is still snoring
like a race - horse! Such
Mornings as these are! Cool,
bright and delightful! What
a paradise, if once that
dreadful disease could only
be exterminated? Went over
to return some calls in
the garrison, last evening,
Mrs. Baldwin & Mrs. SicklesAmes
are both very pleasant-
Must stop to write Genl
Sternberg a short note.
Take care of yourselfes, You
precious fat pair of sweet
girls- Boo! Boo!
